Award.AwardTitle: CCRI: Planning: Towards Building a Community Data Infrastructure for CyberSecurity Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The long-term vision of this project is to create a multi-campus data collection and sharing infrastructure for use by machine-learning cybersecurity and privacy researchers. These datasets will be multimodal in nature (network logs, host logs, authentication logs for kill-chain detection), provide continuous data (for long-term temporal and topological analysis), and be timely in nature (necessary to handle the constantly evolving nature of cyber-attacks). The specific initial steps under this Planning Grant are: (i) organize a workshop to engage the community to formulate a vision and roadmap for this infrastructure and to discuss legal, ethical, privacy, organizational and sustainability considerations, and (ii) create a team of multiple data providers and data users and submit a Grand Ensemble CCRI proposal to build and use the data infrastructure.<br/><br/>The envisioned infrastructure will be invaluable for detecting zero-day (new, previously unseen) attacks and large-scale attacks with complex kill-chains, e.g., the Wannacry ransomware attack, Mirai Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks and Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) attacks. It will be built with input from a selected group of early adopters, i.e., data users who can develop and test their machine learning techniques. Later, the Shibboleth Single Sign-On Access of Incommon Federation members will be used to broaden access to the entire CISE community. Community outreach and dissemination activities are part of the planning grant workshop. A number of undergraduate and graduate students will participate in this project at University of Virginia (UVA), Indiana University (IU), and George Washington University (GWU). Diversity enhancing activities are planned through centers at UVA and IU, and the GWU co-PIâ€™s research Lab.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the project, "CCRI: Planning: Towards Building a Community Data Infrastructure for Cybersecurity Research," was the development of a plan to create a multi-campus and sharing research infrastructure for use by machine-learning cybersecurity and privacy researchers, and the formulation of a vision and roadmap for this infrastructure and to discuss legal, ethical, privacy, organizational and sustainability considerations. Originally planned as a one-year exercise, NSF granted a one-year, no-cost extension because of COVID.

The project had several outcomes. The first was the organization of a workshop that brought together academic researchers, government funding agencies, and industry to formulate a vision and roadmap for creating a multi-campus data collection and sharing infrastructure for use by machine-learning cybersecurity and privacy researchers. The virtual workshop was held on July 27?28, 2021. There were 83 workshop participants.The result of the workshop was a report that discussed key questions and concerns that should be addressed in designing and building the infrastructure. Key questions were:

  • What data to collect?
  • The importance of preserving the privacy of individuals who contribute data.
  • The tension between making the data open, preserving privacy, and supporting the reproducibility of research results, and
  • How to sustain the collection, curation, and storage of these enormous data sets.

The second project outcome was the organization of a workshop, ML for Cybersecurity (ML4Cyber), held in conjunction with the 2022 International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML) located in Baltimore, Maryland. The workshop's goal was to build a mutual comprehensive awareness of the problem and solution spaces across the greater ML community and the Cybersecurity/ML for Cybersecurity communities. There were five contributed papers, two keynote presentations, nine short presentations, and nine posters. The workshop included a panel discussion on benchmark datasets,

The third outcome was the June 2022 grant proposal submission to the CISE Community Research Infrastructure Program (CCRI). The proposal targeted the Grand Community Infrastructure (Grand) class of awards. The collaborative proposal was a joint effort of the University of Virginia, Virginia Tech, and Old Dominion University. While NSF declined to fund the proposal, the PIs are revising the proposal to address some of the feedback received from the reviewers. This revision will be submitted to the new Community Infrastructure in Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CIRC) program.
